results.title: Cleverman character design
results.creator_credit: Jacob Nash, Ryan Griffen and Goalpost Pictures
results.brief_description: Stories of the “hairy man” are told by countless First Peoples across Australia and were used as the basis for the visionary dystopian sci-fi show Cleverman, which reimagined the Hairy people (known as ‘Hairies’ in the show) as heroes harassed and hunted by the government.

constellations_primary.name: Cleverman
constellations_primary.description: Cleverman is dystopian sci-fi with a difference. With a predominantly Indigenous cast and senior crew, the series explores Aboriginal origin stories in a contemporary context, while examining themes of class, racism and power.

results.description:
No matter the country or language spoken, stories of the “hairy man” are told by countless First Nations peoples across Australia. These stories were used as the basis for the visionary dystopian sci-fi show Cleverman, which reimagined the Hairy people (known as ‘Hairies’ in the show) as heroes harassed and hunted by the government.   

Concept creator Ryan Griffen and production designer Jacob Nash worked with Weta Workshop to transform their actors into these extraordinary characters. They sketched concepts to establish a visual style, and these sketches were then used to create costumes, wigs and prosthetics.   

The results are some of the most iconic characters to appear on an Australian TV show, which was already groundbreaking for exploring Aboriginal origin stories in a contemporary context while examining class, racism and power.
description_for_label:
No matter the country or language spoken, stories of the “hairy man” are told by countless First Nations peoples across Australia. These stories were used as the basis for the visionary dystopian sci-fi show Cleverman, which reimagined the Hairy people (known as ‘Hairies’ in the show) as heroes harassed and hunted by the government.   

Concept creator Ryan Griffen and production designer Jacob Nash worked with Weta Workshop to transform their actors into these extraordinary characters. They sketched concepts to establish a visual style, and these sketches were then used to create costumes, wigs and prosthetics.   

The results are some of the most iconic characters to appear on an Australian TV show, which was already groundbreaking for exploring Aboriginal origin stories in a contemporary context while examining class, racism and power.

results.title: Prosthetic Transformations
results.brief_description: Odd Studio turn a young woman into a witch through prosthetics and makeup, in process that involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors.

constellations_primary.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

results.description:
There’s a joke that actors who want to win an Oscar should dramatically transform their physical appearance. Picture Nicole Kidman, unrecognisable as Virginia Woolf in her Oscar-winning role in The Hours (2002), or Heath Ledger, who was posthumously awarded an Academy Award for playing the savagely scarred Joker in The Dark Knight (2008). Those iconic transformations are all done through extensive makeup and hairstyling coupled with prosthetics, like the kind that Australian company Odd Studio used to win an Oscar for their work on Mad Max: Fury Road (2015).  

Here Odd Studio demonstrate their skills by turning a young woman into a witch. The process involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors into all variety of shapes, faces and features.
description_for_label:
There’s a joke that actors who want to win an Oscar should dramatically transform their physical appearance. Picture Nicole Kidman, unrecognisable as Virginia Woolf in her Oscar-winning role in The Hours (2002), or Heath Ledger, who was posthumously awarded an Academy Award for playing the savagely scarred Joker in The Dark Knight (2008). Those iconic transformations are all done through extensive makeup and hairstyling coupled with prosthetics, like the kind that Australian company Odd Studio used to win an Oscar for their work on Mad Max: Fury Road (2015).  

Here Odd Studio demonstrate their skills by turning a young woman into a witch. The process involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors into all variety of shapes, faces and features.
